alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. I always cook on a budget. It's part of my background, part of my DNA I guess. And it's the education of a good cook to be able to use what we have. And in that case, today, I have all kind of canned here. I have some lentils here. I have a can of corn. I have a can of chicken flesh. And I'm going to do a dish with it. I could do, of course, a soup with all of that. I could do 1 thing or another. But at some point, you take a decision. So I have about 2 and 1 1⁄2 cup of water here. 2 and 1⁄2 cup of water. I have about a cup and 1⁄2, which is half a pound, of lentil. I'm going to put, well, a good cup of onion in there. And of course, the lentil will take a little while to cook. A few clove of garlic. You can never use too much garlic for me. Okay, this. I think a little pinch maybe of a teaspoon of Italian seasoning or herb de Provence, 1 of those things, you know. Teaspoon of it. Some salt, of course. Not too much because I'm going to put, I think, a tablespoon of chicken base here to get more taste. So a good tablespoon of this. Now you bring that to a boil and you cook it about 40 minutes, 40-45 minutes. We'll see. Sometimes depending on how dry the lentils are. And then I have a can of corn so I will Put probably, I should probably do it now, put most of the juice in there. And the juice of the chicken as well. I get some taste there. Okay. Stir it. Good. And that should probably be enough for like 6 people, so very inexpensive. So, whoop, my lentils are cooked. Yeah, that's it. 40 minutes. 40 minutes. Sometimes they take a little longer, and sometimes a bit less. They are tender. And then I'm going to put the curry. So that will extend my dish quite a lot, and like the turn of chicken. All of that, I'll bring that to a boil. Heat it up. Garnish it with a bit of scallion or parsley. That's it. Or parsley. That's it. And I have quite a lot of a big casserole here that would serve easy 6 people. All right. So here it is, let me taste it. A minimal amount of chicken. Here I have 10 ounce kind of chicken, but it will serve 6 people. A bit of pepper. And a little bit of olive oil on top like this. And have a big, A big casserole dish here. Again, tiny bit of olive oil. Parsley or chives on top again, And this is it, the fricassee au blanc with chicken. Happy cooking. You

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. I always cook on a budget. It's part of my background, part of my DNA I guess. And it's the education of a good cook to be able to use what we have. And in that case, today, I have all kind of canned here.

I have some lentils here. I have a can of corn. I have a can of chicken flesh. And I'm going to do a dish with it. I could do, of course, a soup with all of that.

I could do 1 thing or another. But at some point, you take a decision. So I have about 2 and 1 1⁄2 cup of water here. 2 and 1⁄2 cup of water. I have about a cup and 1⁄2, which is half a pound, of lentil.

I'm going to put, well, a good cup of onion in there. And of course, the lentil will take a little while to cook. A few clove of garlic. You can never use too much garlic for me. Okay, this.

I think a little pinch maybe of a teaspoon of Italian seasoning or herb de Provence, 1 of those things, you know. Teaspoon of it. Some salt, of course. Not too much because I'm going to put, I think, a tablespoon of chicken base here to get more taste. So a good tablespoon of this.

Now you bring that to a boil and you cook it about 40 minutes, 40-45 minutes. We'll see. Sometimes depending on how dry the lentils are. And then I have a can of corn so I will Put probably, I should probably do it now, put most of the juice in there. And the juice of the chicken as well.

I get some taste there. Okay. Stir it. Good. And that should probably be enough for like 6 people, so very inexpensive.

So, whoop, my lentils are cooked. Yeah, that's it. 40 minutes. 40 minutes. Sometimes they take a little longer, and sometimes a bit less.

They are tender. And then I'm going to put the curry. So that will extend my dish quite a lot, and like the turn of chicken. All of that, I'll bring that to a boil. Heat it up.

Garnish it with a bit of scallion or parsley. That's it. Or parsley. That's it. And I have quite a lot of a big casserole here that would serve easy 6 people.

All right. So here it is, let me taste it. A minimal amount of chicken. Here I have 10 ounce kind of chicken, but it will serve 6 people. A bit of pepper.

And a little bit of olive oil on top like this. And have a big, A big casserole dish here. Again, tiny bit of olive oil. Parsley or chives on top again, And this is it, the fricassee au blanc with chicken. Happy cooking.

You

I always cook on a budget.
It's part of my background, part of my DNA I guess.
And it's the education of a good cook to be able to use what we have.
And in that case, today, I have all kind of canned here.
I have some lentils here.
I have a can of corn.
I have a can of chicken flesh.
And I'm going to do a dish with it.
I could do, of course, a soup with all of that.

I'm going to put, well, a good cup of onion in there.
And of course, the lentil will take a little while to cook.
A few clove of garlic.
You can never use too much garlic for me.
Okay, this.

Teaspoon of it.
Some salt, of course.
Not too much because I'm going to put, I think, a tablespoon of chicken base here to get more taste.
So a good tablespoon of this.
Now you bring that to a boil and you cook it about 40 minutes, 40-45 minutes.
We'll see.
Sometimes depending on how dry the lentils are.
And then I have a can of corn so I will Put probably, I should probably do it now, put most of the juice in there.
